title: Random roadside drugs and alcohol testing 'significant step forward'
subtitle: Measures 'essential' for Malta's reputation as a safe tourism destination
content: The Malta Hotels and Restaurants Association on Wednesday “strongly supported” random roadside testing for drugs and alcohol saying it will have a positive impact on Malta's reputation as a safe tourism destination. The association said the introduction of random roadside testing is a “significant step forward” in addressing reckless behaviour on the roads and protecting lives. “These measures are not only essential for upholding the rule of law but also for reinforcing Malta’s international reputation as a safe and welcoming destination,” the MHRA said. Prime Minister Robert Abela and Home Affairs Minister Byron Camilleri announced on Tuesday announced that police will be given the power to randomly test drivers for alcohol or drugs while laws will be revised to ensure anyone involved in fatal crashes while driving under the influence is sent to prison.   Recognising that safety and security are “decisive success factors” for Malta as a “quality tourism destination”, the MHRA said tourists and residents must feel assured that Malta provides a safe and orderly environment, free from risks that undermine wellbeing and public trust. The association stressed that better sustainable tourism management is “inseparable” from responsible enforcement and strong deterrents against behaviour that endanger society. “These reforms will help ensure a higher standard of living for residents and the local community, while delivering outstanding, safe experiences for even the most discerning tourists,” the MHRA added.
top_image_caption: The MHRA says it "strongly supports" the introduction of random roadside testing for drugs and alcohol as it will make Malta safer not just for residents for also for tourists. File photo: Shutterstock

title: Case continues of drunk driver in Baħar iċ-Ċagħaq crash, driver granted bail
subtitle: Yoana Valentinova Gatt has admitted to drink driving but denies reckless driving charge
content: A woman involved in a Baħar ic-Cagħaq collision that left a motorcyclist seriously injured has been granted bail. Yoana Valentinova Gatt, a 44-year-old Bulgarian national living in St Paul’s Bay, admitted earlier this week to causing grievous bodily harm through negligence to the motorcyclist, damaging the victim’s motorcycle, driving under the influence and drink driving. She denies the reckless driving charge, and the case continues with respect to that charge. The incident took place on August 17 when Valentinova Gatt hit the motorcycle from the rear, injuring its driver, a 53-year-old Belgian national living in Gżira. Eyewitnesses who testified earlier this week explained how five men had lifted the woman’s car, which had its engine still running, to free the trapped motorcyclist. The motorcyclist was placed in the recovery position until the emergency services arrived at the scene. A breathalyser test revealed Valentinova Gatt was six times over the legal limit, with the test marking 124.9 μg/100ml (microgrammes of alcohol per 100ml breath). On Friday morning, the court granted the woman bail against a €2,000 deposit and a €10,000 personal guarantee. She was ordered to sign the bail book twice a week. Magistrate Antoine Agius Bonnici presided. Police inspector Nathan Bugeja prosecuted. Legal aid lawyer Nadya Fiott appeared for the accused.

title: Skip and run: truck smashes Rabat balcony and flees
subtitle: Second time in a decade that a truck has crashed into the same Rabat home
content: A truck hit the balcony of a Rabat home and kept going without stopping - and the property owner says it is the second time a truck has damaged the house. The balcony subsequently had to be dismantled as it was deemed unsafe following the impact.  Cyril Spiteri Staines and his wife received a call from "shocked" neighbours just after 9pm on Wednesday, who told them a truck had hit their Rabat property and kept going.  Neighbours told them they saw the vehicle responsible but did not note its number plate as it was too dark to see.  “I am more angry than shocked. This savage just breaks our property and drives off like nothing happened,” said Spiteri Staines, 53. Neighbours described the truck as a skiploader without a skip on the back.  The couple live in St Julian's and the Rabat property is currently unoccupied.   Police and Civil Protection Department officials arrived on site shortly after being informed. A report was filed and, after assessing the damage, authorities decided the balcony was too dangerous to leave standing. It was pulled down shortly afterwards. “I tip my hat to the authorities; they did an outstanding job on our end,” said Spiteri Staines.    “Unbelievably, this isn’t even the first time that our house was hit by a truck,” he added. Spiteri Staines explained that around a decade ago, the same house, but on the side facing Triq Tal-Virtù, was damaged when a truck carrying animal feed crashed into it. That time, the driver took responsibility. He said he hoped the outcome this time would be the same. “If the person who crashed into our place was in any way a responsible person, they would have stopped to assess the damage and take accountability, but they didn’t. So now we want them caught and for them to fix the damage.” He is appealing to anyone who may have witnessed the incident or has CCTV footage to contact him at cspiteristaines@gmail.com.

title: Maltese couple killed in Sicily head-on collision with truck
subtitle: Maltese 'senior citizens' pronounced dead after crash on Catania-Ragusa motorway
content: An elderly Maltese couple were killed in a car accident on a Sicily motorway on Wednesday.  Sources confirmed the husband, aged 73, and his 69-year old wife were driving a Toyota Yaris with a Maltese registration number plate on the Catania – Ragusa motorway close to Lentini when they were involved in a head-on collision with a truck at 3pm. Local radio station Radio Una Voce Vicina reported that emergency services from Augusta, the fire brigade and a helicopter ambulance were called on site.  The couple were extracted from the car but medical officers confirmed they had been killed on impact, reports said. The bodies were transferred to the mortuary at Lentini hospital.   The motorway was closed in both directions for several hours during the investigation. title: Watch: Mildred’s last selfie of joy before death struck
subtitle: Family of crash victim recount the night that changed their lives
content: Less than an hour before she was fatally struck by a car, Mildred Azzopardi shared a final snapshot of the simple joys she cherished most: tea and cheesecakes by the sea with her husband. At 9.10pm, the 62-year-old mother posted a selfie in the family WhatsApp group, ‘The Fam’, captioned in Maltese: “bela te u pastizzi tal-Serkin u ħallieh ħa jħabbat” (a cup of tea and Serkin cheesecakes and let it roll), signing off with an angel emoji. By 9.45pm, tragedy had struck. “She sent it with a smiley of an angel – thankfully, we all saw it,” recalled her children Cain, 35, Janice, 32, Amy, 26, and Maria, 22. Speaking for the first time since the accident that claimed their mother’s life and left their father still in hospital, the siblings described how the crash turned their world upside down in an instant.  “Every night when we were little. she would tell us good night and remind us: ‘You are not alone’. As kids, it gave us the chills. And she was right – we are not alone. The support has been overwhelming. At least we have one another. When one of us breaks down, the others help,” they say.

title: No entry sign put up at Mġiebaħ Bay as danger looms right on top of bathers
subtitle: The sign was put up hours after Times of Malta queried the lack of safety measures in place
content: The Public Works authorities on Tuesday evening placed a ‘Danger no entry’ warning sign at Mġiebaħ Bay, hours after Times of Malta queried a lack of safety measures in place and four months after a government report identified unstable rock formations as a “significant risk to public safety”.  The report had said that action should be taken “as soon as possible to prevent any avoidable incidents”.  It remains unclear whether any further safety measures will follow the placement of the no-entry sign. Mġiebaħ Bay, in Mellieħa’s Selmun area, is a swimming spot favoured by those wanting to avoid crowds. Pictures posted on social media and others taken by Times of Malta show deep cracks in rock formations just above a flat, clay part of Mġiebaħ that is popular with bathers.  Frenki Dragan Crnjakovic, who flagged the issue on the Facebook group ‘The BEST of Malta’, said he highlighted the issue last year. “A huge chunk of rock is waiting for its moment to crash into the sea. I wrote about this last year but it seems my post didn’t reach many people. Be kind – share with your friends. I believe that it will also reach the official services that will mark or fence off these dangerous areas,” he said.  Mellieħa mayor Gabriel Micallef said he first reported the issue to the police and several government entities last April. He pointed to a particular rock formation that seemed close to dislodging onto the crowd. By May, a report commissioned by the police and drawn up by the Public Works Department’s Project Design and Engineering Directorate confirmed the danger. “It has been observed that large boulders are gradually becoming dislodged due to ongoing coastal erosion,” the report, dated May 9, says. “This natural process is giving rise to areas that pose a significant risk to public safety, especially as the summer season approaches and the bay is expected to attract a high number of visitors for sunbathing and swimming,” it says. The report said that, besides the cracks in the rock formation highlighted by Micallef, other rock formations in other parts of the bay were dangerous. “In view of the above, I strongly recommend that a qualified geotechnical engineer be urgently commissioned to carry out a comprehensive assessment of the site. The objective of this evaluation should be to identify zones of potential danger and advise on any necessary mitigation measures,” the report says. “Given the imminent increase in public use of this location, this assessment should be undertaken as soon as possible to prevent any avoidable incidents.” Correspondence provided to Times of Malta by the Mellieħa mayor shows that the Lands Authority was alerted to the problem. Micallef said that the last communication he had from the authority was in June, when the Lands Authority and the council agreed to install danger signs. “Kindly note that danger signs have been ordered and I will update you with the date of installation,” the e-mail, dated June 24, said. Questions have been sent to the lands ministry. Last year, 22-year-old Mirabelle Falzon died when she was hit by falling rocks at a popular spot in an area known as Munxar, in the limits of St Thomas Bay. The ruins of an 18th-century military battery, known as Riħama, are perched on the cliff overlooking the site. After the incident, several signs were put up, warning that swimming in the area is prohibited, and a fence was erected around the battery itself.  A magisterial inquiry into the tragedy said reports about the dangerous state of the coastal battery in Marsascala, made in the months and years before the collapse killed Falzon, were lost in the bureaucracy of government entities.  The magistrate recommended that a single entity should be responsible for receiving reports about state-owned and private buildings, as well as abandoned buildings and structures like bastions and cliffs that presented a danger to the public. In a statement reacting to the conclusions, the government said it will be implementing the court’s recommendation for there to be one entity “that will receive reports about government buildings or private buildings, as well as about walls, cliffs, or abandoned buildings that pose a danger to the public”.
top_image_caption: The site at risk of a potentially deadly rockfall. (Chris Sant Fournier)

title: Motorcyclist seriously injured after losing control of motorbike
subtitle: The incident happened at around 7.30am in Msida
content: A motorcyclist was left with serious injuries after a traffic accident on Thursday morning.   In a statement, police said the 33-year-old man appeared to have lost control of the Wottan Storm motorcycle he was riding at around 7.30am on Dun Karm Street, Msida.  He was treated at the scene before being taken to Mater Dei Hospital, where his injuries were certified as serious.   Investigations are ongoing.

title: Watch: The moment car crashes into Marsa building
subtitle: Four men uninjured, private residence and car damaged
content: Four men escaped injury when the driver lost control of his car and smashed into the facade of a building in Marsa causing some damage. The incident happened on Friday afternoon in Triq Isouard when CCTV footage captured a Mercedes driving round a corner at the top of the street, swerving across the opposite lane and crashing with some speed, climbing the pavement and into the facade of a private residence.  Just seconds earlier, a woman was walking in the street on the opposite side of the road but she stepped off the road and onto the safety of the pavement just as the car crashed into the building opposite. The Mercedes also hit the back of a Citroen parked outside the building, shoving it slightly forward. The four men climbed out of the vehicle seemingly unharmed as they surveyed the extensive damage caused both to the front of the car and to the facade. Stones were seen falling off the facade after the impact. It is not yet known if the owners of the residence were at home at the time of the accident. LESA CEO Svetlick Flores said "this is normal business for us to see a collision involving a vehicle and a building or a fence". Last month, a cab driver crashed into a hairdressing salon in Santa Venera causing more than €10,000 in damages. The driver was charged with drink driving.  This is a developing story. More to follow.

title: ‘All hell broke loose’: Marsa resident recounts crash that damaged his home
subtitle: Piscopo's wife, granddaughter were about to go outside when accident happened
content: Ray Piscopo’s wife was carrying their three-year-old granddaughter to take her outside when, just as she placed her hand on the door lock, a deafening blast rang out. Shattered glass and falling masonry followed. In terror, the 70-year-old screamed: “A bomb, a bomb, a bomb.” It was the moment when a Mercedes crashed into the façade of their Marsa home on Friday afternoon. title: Man accused of Bidnija murder charged with earlier ‘road rage’ attack
subtitle: Water delivery ends in an altercation
content: A man accused of murdering a driver after a minor road collision has been charged with a second alleged road rage incident that took place months before the fatal shooting. Mohamed Hamdan, 46, appeared in court yesterday to face a string of driving offences  over a January incident in St Paul’s Bay, in which he allegedly rammed his truck into a car following a traffic dispute. The incident, caught on camera and exclusively revealed by Times of Malta, involved Hamdan allegedly attempting to park his truck to make a water delivery to a hotel. Police inspector Warren Galea told the court that the alleged victim, driving a red Mazda, had overtaken Hamdan and blocked his access to the designated delivery spot on Triq it-Turisti.   The two men exited their vehicles and initially exchanged words. The situation quickly escalated, and a passenger had to intervene to separate them. Hamdan then returned to his truck and drove into the Mazda, which was later declared a total loss. Three other parked vehicles were also extensively damaged. The court heard that the accused was arrested at the time but released on police bail until February 26, pending the submission of medical documentation by the alleged victim. Despite repeated visits by Hamdan to the Qawra police station to seek updates, the requested documents were not submitted until March. The alleged victim presented a medical certificate and vehicle damage valuation report, both dated January. Hamdan also sustained a scratch, which was certified as slight injuries. Hamdan was called back to the police station on April 15. He requested to have his lawyer, Nicholas Mifsud, present before any interrogation. However, inspector Galea explained that due to Mifsud’s involvement in a high-profile jury case, the interview was postponed. Before a new date could be set, the fatal Bidnija shooting occurred. Hamdan was arrested and charged with murdering Jean Paul Busuttil in yet another traffic dispute. Given the circumstances, police decided to file the earlier road rage charges on July 4 without conducting a formal interrogation. Hamdan pleaded not guilty to wilful damage to a car, slightly injuring the driver, damaging three parked cars through negligent and reckless driving, dangerous driving and recidivism. The alleged victim took the stand yesterday. Cautioned that he could face charges himself, the man chose to testify. He said he had been collecting employees from the Buġibba Hotel at around 6.30am when Hamdan’s truck reversed towards him. He claimed he tried to manoeuvre around the truck, asking Hamdan to let him pass so the latter could park. The witness described Hamdan exiting the truck and allegedly swearing and trying to punch him. He said his employees stepped in to defuse the situation, and as he returned to close the back passenger door, Hamdan drove his truck into his car and then several others. Under cross-examination, the alleged victim admitted that his car was in the middle of the road but insisted he had no alternative route to where he was going. He denied pushing Hamdan but admitted to “blocking” him when the accused attempted to strike him. Lawyer Jacob Magri, representing the alleged victim as parte civile, requested a protection order following the testimony. The court, presided over by Magistrate Leonard Caruana, is expected to rule on the matter from chambers. The case continues in October. Police inspector Warren Galea prosecuted. Lawyer Nicholas Mifsud assisted Hamdan. Lawyers Arthur Azzopardi and Jacob Magri are assisting alleged victim.

title: Woman cleared of causing collision with six parked cars
subtitle: Prosecutors failed to prove that the accused was driving the car that caused the crash, court says
content:
A court has cleared a woman of crashing a car into six parked vehicles after the prosecution failed to prove she was the driver. The incident happened in Naxxar Road, Birkirkara, on March 19, 2022. Esther Mifsud was arraigned before Magistrate Yana Micallef Stafrace and accused of dangerous and reckless driving, damaging the six parked cars due to negligence, and driving under the influence of alcohol. She denied the charges. The court observed that affidavits presented in court were “inconclusive” and “confusing” as to who was actually driving the vehicle at the time of the incident. It pointed out that jurisprudence laid down that the evidence on identity needs to be “clear” and “unequivocal”. In this case the prosecution failed to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused was driving the vehicle at the time of the incident and that she was driving under the influence. It was also noted that while the police had alleged that bodycam used by officers on the scene was switched on at the time of the incident, footage was never presented in court. “Had this evidence been presented, it would clearly have helped the court to identify the person behind the wheel,” Magistrate Yana Micallef Stafrace said. The court acquitted Mifsud of all charges brought against her.

Police inspector Diane Vella prosecuted. Lawyer Charles Mercieca appeared for the accused.

title: Autopsy results of Croatia car tragedy victims expected on Monday
subtitle: Bonnici and Gambin family members are travelling to Croatia on Saturday
content: Autopsy results of the two couples who died when their rental car plunged into the sea while on holiday in Croatia will be published on Monday.  Croatian sources told Times of Malta the Institute of Forensic Medicine in Rijeka, which is carrying out the autopsies, will have details of the results on Monday.  Jeremy Gambin, 68, and his wife Lorraine, 67, died alongside Kevin Bonnici, 67, and his wife Alexandra, 66. They were travelling together on the scenic Adriatic Coast when the car they were in veered off the road and into the sea on Thursday afternoon. The four were good friends and all lived in Swieqi.  Autopsy results could help shed light on the dynamics of the crash, with Croatian media having reported that the initial suspicion is that the person driving the vehicle may have become ill while driving, leading to the crash.   Jeremy Gambin was a basketball coach at Luxol and a former player who represented Malta at the 1987 Games of Small States of Europe in Monaco. He was also a PE Teacher at St Michael’s Foundation. He and his wife Lorraine, whose official name is Cynthia, had three children and several grandchildren.   Kevin Bonnici worked in the cab business and served as a company director of two separate Y-Plate fleet firms. He previously worked for Air Malta in the airline's finance, flight ops and engineering departments. He and his wife Alexandra had two children and various grandchildren.   Sources told Times of Malta that family members were travelling to Croatia on Saturday, and forensics will continue with the autopsy.  The accident happened at 4.20pm on Thursday, on the D8 state road near Bunica, just south of Senj. Police said the vehicle, travelling from Rijeka towards Senj, is believed to have lost control on a left-hand bend, veered right, struck two stone barriers and fell around 70 metres down a ravine before ending up in the water. Police officer Jasmin Mujaković from the Senj Police Station was among the first to arrive at the scene of the horrific accident, 24sata reported. He surfaced several times for air and then went down under the surface again, trying to find a way to reach the victims. A Croatian diver with over 30 years of experience has described Thursday’s fatal car accident that killed four Maltese tourists as the most difficult intervention of his career. Renato Huba said that while he had similar interventions before, he described the accident as “one of the most difficult”, he told Croatian newsroom. “I prepared myself for the worst situation, but that was not enough; this was much worse,” Huba said.

title: Husband’s vigil for wife in coma after crash that claimed unborn baby
subtitle: Crowdfunding campaign launched to take Tonamol back home
content: A 29-year-old woman has been in a coma for almost three months after she was hit by a car while five months pregnant – an accident that also claimed the life of her unborn son. Tonamol Baby, an Indian national, was struck on July 16 and has remained in Mater Dei Hospital’s neurosurgical ward since. Her husband, Jacob Tom, visits her daily, gently speaking to her and holding her hand – a quiet routine that began after the crash that changed everything for the couple. “It’s our first baby. A boy,” says Tom, 34. “Unfortunately, July 20 was my birthday, and my boy passed on July 19.” He paused before adding, “I don’t feel angry. I feel sad.” Tom, a man of small build, smiles as he steps away from his wife for a few minutes to walk out of the ward for the interview. He sits on a blue chair in the waiting room and places two mobile phones on the chair beside him: he carries her mobile around with him. He has been there since 8am. This is where he spends his days – up until it’s time for him to go to work at 6pm. “I am near her every day. In Malta, I am alone. I want to take her home to India. I think having family will help her get better faster,” he says. This is why he has launched a crowdfunding campaign to raise the money he needs to take his wife back home, where she can be surrounded by family and continue her care. But this will cost about €50,000, which he cannot afford. An accident that changed everything  Tom came to Malta four years ago and initially worked as a bartender. After completing several courses, he became a sommelier and now works with the db Group. He got married to Tonamol, who he met in the area they are from, Kerala in the South of India. They married three years ago, and she moved to Malta a year later, initially working as a carer at Mater Dei Hospital. After she obtained her bridge course, she became a nurse and was based at St Vincent de Paul Residence. Tom usually joined her on her commute to work every day. “I will wake up when she gets ready for the duty and we take the bus from Buġibba where we live. After I drop her off, I will come to sleep,” he says.  Holding on to hope Doctors told him there was no hope. They did not expect her to make it beyond 48 hours. But she did. And now days became weeks and months. “She is still in a coma state, but she is totally different now. I can see almost the same face. She started to open her eyes. There is eye contact, but she is still not responding. There has been miniature progress from the first day but, for me, there were big changes,” he says, insisting that he is hopeful. He spends his day near her. For over a month, he did not report to work. But he has now decided to return – for his mental health and to earn the money he needs. “Recently I started working – my company, which I belong to, are very supportive. Every day I'm here… I’m away from here just for work. I work from 6pm to 1am. I get home at 3am. By 8am I am near her until it's time to go to work,” he says. But here in Malta he has no family support. This is why he would like to take his wife back to India where she will be provided with care for her condition and surrounded by family. But getting her home is too expensive. She would have to be transported in a medical ambulance for the cost of €20,000 and the hospital care is estimated to cost another €30,000. “I will be with her for a couple of months. Then, I hope, she will be okay, and I will bring her back with me.” Anyone who would like to help Tom take his wife home to India can access the crowdfunding page https://gogetfunding.com/prayers-and-support-needed-for-tonamol-babys-recovery/

title: Couples killed in Croatia travelled together for 30 years without an accident
subtitle: Families of victims visit the site of the tragedy
content: The two Maltese couples killed when their car plunged into the sea in Croatia last Thursday had been travelling together for more than 30 years and had never experienced a single accident. The victims – Jeremy and Lorraine Gambin and Kevin and Sandra Bonnici – were lifelong friends and cousins who regularly holidayed together across Europe and beyond. “They were not only cousins but best friends who travelled all over the world together. They’ve driven around together for tens of thousands of kilometres,” Justin Gambin, one of the victims’ sons told Times of Malta. The fatal crash occurred on the D8 state road near Bunica, close to the coastal town of Senj, when their rented car struck two stone barriers and fell some 70 metres into the sea below. Croatian emergency divers described the recovery operation as one of the most difficult they had ever carried out.  Relatives of the victims, including their children, are currently in Senj, where on Monday they laid flowers near the crash site in memory of their loved ones. In their first comments to the media since the tragedy, the Gambin and Bonnici families expressed deep gratitude to the Croatian authorities and local community for the “incredible support” shown in the aftermath of the tragedy.  All the victims’ personal belongings have since been returned to the families who are now waiting for the autopsy results.  Meanwhile, questions have been raised about the safety of the D8 road, where certain stretches lack adequate barriers to prevent cars from plunging into the sea below. "While the stone bollards along the road may appear protective, they were likely insufficient to prevent a vehicle from veering off the road,” said Jonathan Gambin, whose 68-year-old brother was among the victims. Gambin said the family hopes that further investigations into the accident will bring some kind of closure.  The tragedy shocked Malta and is believed to be the highest death toll of a crash involving Maltese nationals abroad.  It came almost exactly a month after another Maltese couple, Doris and Manuel Buhagiar, were killed in a car crash in Sicily.

title: Traffic collision case collapses over identification failure and police error
content:
A St Paul’s Bay man accused of causing a traffic collision has been acquitted after the alleged victim failed to identify him in court and police failed to follow proper procedures during the investigation.
Dennis Attard, 49, of Triq l-Imsida, Santa Venera, faced five charges stemming from a collision on 23 September 2024 in Triq Censu Tabone, St Paul’s Bay, including reckless driving, causing involuntary damage, driving without a licence, driving an unlicensed vehicle, and driving without insurance.
The case centred on a collision between Attard’s vehicle and a motorcycle ridden by Marland Herman Jones.
Jones told the court he was riding down a narrow street when a car “just kind of jumped in” and pulled out in front of him. “I braked as hard as I could but I hit the I believe his door or the front right quarter panel,” he testified, adding that he “just kind of fell over and jumped up cursing.”
Jones explained that the driver claimed he had to leave urgently because “his daughter was giving birth.” They exchanged phone numbers via WhatsApp, but when Jones attempted to contact him, he received no response despite seeing the messages had been viewed. “I tried to contact him again, no answer. He viewed the I saw it through the messaging app. I could tell that he watched it,” Jones testified.
However, when asked to identify the accused in court, Jones admitted: “Actually at at this date I can’t recognize him in court, if this is the gentleman, I don’t quite recognize him, I have to be honest.” He explained he had identified someone at the police station “over 8 months ago” but “couldn’t tell you now.”
The defence suggested Jones had hit the car from behind, but Jones firmly rejected this, stating repeatedly: “That’d be completely incorrect” and “That’d be incredibly incorrect.”
Magistrate Yana Micallef Stafrace dismissed all charges on Monday, ruling that Jones “did not recognise the accused in Court” and noting his claimed identification at the police station “does not result from the police affidavit.”
Moreover, the court found that “on the day of the collision the right to silence was not administered to the accused as required by law.”
Court therefore concluded that “the evidence does not provide beyond reasonable doubt all the elements of the crime, and therefore the imputations have not been proven to the degree required in the criminal field.”
Attard chose not to testify and was acquitted of all charges.

title: Watch: Partial building collapse in central Madrid injures three and leaves four missing
content:
A partial building collapse in central Madrid has injured at least three construction workers and left four others unaccounted for, emergency officials confirmed on Tuesday. The incident occurred at a renovation site near Plaza Mayor, a busy area in the heart of the Spanish capital.
Search underway for missing workers
Firefighters and rescue teams were deployed immediately after several floors of the building gave way, causing a cascade collapse that reached the basement level.
According to Francisco Martín Aguirre, the central government’s representative in the Madrid region, the damage was “very severe”, and assessments were underway to determine whether neighbouring buildings had been compromised.
Deputy Mayor Inmaculada Sanz said that search efforts were ongoing for four missing individuals, three men and one woman. Emergency responders were using drones to scan the wreckage while nearby properties were being evacuated as a precaution.
Initial reports from Madrid’s emergency services indicated that three workers had sustained injuries, none of which were serious. Mayor José Luis Martínez-Almeida later confirmed that one of the injured had been taken to hospital.
Earlier estimates from Martín Aguirre suggested that up to 10 people might have been hurt, but municipal authorities later revised the figure down to three. Emergency officials maintained that all injuries were minor.
Witness accounts
The collapse sent shockwaves through the surrounding streets. Witnesses described hearing a powerful explosion before a massive cloud of dust engulfed the area.
“There was an enormous blast that shattered all the glass,” said Milagros García Benito, who works at a nearby hair salon. “You couldn’t see a thing, everything was white. Then the firefighters and police arrived almost immediately.”
Police cordoned off the site, which was soon filled with ambulances, fire engines, and emergency personnel as crowds of onlookers gathered.
Sanz warned that the rescue and stabilisation work would be extensive, stating that “the amount of rubble is very significant” and that operations “will last quite some time, possibly several days”.
The building, originally an office block, was being converted into a hotel after receiving planning approval from Madrid City Hall in February. Land registry data lists the structure as a six-storey property covering roughly 6,745 square metres (about 73,000 square feet).
Investigation underway
Authorities have not yet determined the cause of the collapse. Engineers and safety inspectors were expected to begin a detailed assessment once rescue operations concluded.
The Madrid municipal police said surrounding buildings would remain evacuated until stability could be guaranteed.
Emergency services continue to work at the site, prioritising the search for the missing workers amid concerns about further structural instability.

title: Motorist admits drink-driving and fleeing the scene of an accident
subtitle: Court fines him €3,000 and suspends his licence for six months
content: A 34-year-old drink-driver who hit a motorcyclist and sped away from the scene was fined €3,000 and had his driving licence suspended for six months on Tuesday. The accident happened on the roundabout of Saqqajja Hill on Sunday. Mario Mifsud, a chef from Qormi, appeared in court on Tuesday accused of driving in a reckless, negligent or dangerous manner, damaging a motorcycle, injuring the motorcyclist and driving under the influence. He was also accused of leaving the scene of the collision. Police inspector Nathan Bugeja explained that the motorcyclist was waiting at the roundabout when he was hit by the car driven by the accused. The driver stopped and upon seeing the victim on the ground, got back in his car and sped off. He then turned up at Qormi police station half an hour later with his father and brother. He smelt of alcohol but refused to take a breathalyser test after consulting with his lawyer. On Tuesday afternoon, he pleaded guilty to the charges. Magistrate Charmaine Galea, found him guilty by his own admission, fined him €3,000 and suspended his driving licence for six months. The court also imposed a 12-point penalty on his licence. Police inspector Nathan Bugeja prosecuted while lawyer Roberto Montalto assisted the accused.

title: Taxi driver knocked out in road rage attack: 'Just asked him politely to move'
subtitle: ‘This isn’t how you should resolve problems in a civilised country’
content: A taxi driver was left unconscious after being repeatedly punched in the head in an apparent road rage incident in Paceville. Motiraj Paudel suffered head injuries in what witnesses described as an unprovoked attack in the early hours of Sunday, at the corner of Triq San Ġorġ and Triq L. Apap. The 43-year-old from Nepal said he was driving along the road when he found it blocked by a badly parked white Mercedes “half on the pavement and half in the road”. “When I told the driver he was parked illegally, he and another man got out of the car and one of them punched me three or four times in the head,” Paudel told Times of Malta. He was knocked out and, after coming to his senses a minute later, a group of women who had witnessed the assault called an ambulance, which took him to Mater Dei Hospital for treatment. “The [taxi] driver was completely peaceful and did nothing to provoke the attack,” a shocked witness said. “We went to the police station immediately to report what we saw but they did not ask for any ID or contact details,” she added. A police spokesperson said a report had not been filed at the time of writing but the victim said he thought his medical report would be sent to the police. Paudel, who was forced to take time off work due to his injuries, said he had been living in Malta for the past six years. 'Racist insults but never a physical assault' He said that, in his four years working as a bus driver and two years as a taxi driver, he had experienced occasional racist insults but never a physical assault. “I just asked him politely to move. This isn’t how you should resolve problems in a civilised country,” he said. The incident follows another reported case of road rage that occurred two days prior, in which three people were involved in a brawl in the middle of Triq Manwel Dimech, in Sliema. Those involved ultimately chose not to pursue the matter with a police report, opting instead to apologise. In May, dashcam footage captured a driver assaulting a tourist attempting to cross a zebra crossing, also in Sliema. In a separate case in June, a road rage dispute in Bidnija allegedly escalated into a fatal shooting. Mohamed Hamdan, 46, denies murdering Jean Paul Busuttil by shooting him with a gun he retrieved from his home following the minor collision.

title: Bodies of Croatian crash victims to be flown home on Friday
subtitle: The funeral of Jeremy and Lorraine Gambin will be held on Saturday
content: The families of the two couples killed in a horrific road crash in Croatia are preparing to bring their loved ones home on Friday. Jeremy and Lorraine Gambin and their best friends Kevin and Sandra Bonnici were killed last Thursday when their Land Rover Discovery plunged off a cliff and veered into the sea on the D8 state road near Bunica, just south of Senj. The funeral of the Gambin couple will be held on Saturday at Balluta church at 9.30am, the victims' son Justin Gambin told Times of Malta. The date of the funeral of the other couple is not yet known.  The four - aged between 66 and 68 - were lifelong friends who regularly holidayed abroad together. In a statement to Times of Malta, the Gambin family said: "Jeremy and Lorraine, humble and loved by all, lived life to the fullest. They left us doing what they loved most with their best friends." Drowning most likely cause of death Meanwhile, autopsy results reported by Croatian media say drowning was the most likely cause of death of the two couples, as only slight injuries were found on the bodies. All four are believed to have been wearing seatbelts. Forensic investigations are ongoing with experts unable to determine what caused the car to veer off the road. Initial reports in the Croatian media that the driver of the vehicle may have become ill while driving, thus leading to the crash, were not verified by the autopsy. The vehicle fell around 70 metres after veering off the road, before crashing into the sea to a depth of at least 11 metres. The investigation was conducted by forensic medicine specialists from the Institute of Forensic Medicine in Rijeka. Relatives of the four victims, including their children, laid flowers near the crash site in memory of their loved ones.  Justin Gambin said his father and Kevin Bonnici were “not only cousins but best friends who travelled all over the world together. They’ve driven around together for tens of thousands of kilometres”. Speaking to Times of Malta on Wednesday, he thanked the Croatian police in Senj for their assistance.  Questions on safety of road Meanwhile, questions have been raised about the safety of the D8 road, where certain stretches lack adequate barriers to prevent cars from plunging into the sea below. Jonathan Gambin, whose brother was among the victims, said that while stone bollards along the road “may appear protective, they were likely insufficient to prevent a vehicle from veering off the road”. He had expressed hope that further investigations into the accident would bring the victims’ relatives a measure of closure. It is not known whether the Senj Bora, the notorious strong northeasterly wind that blows along the Adriatic coast of Croatia, could have potentially contributed to the accident. There has also been some speculation in the Croatian media that an oncoming car could also have distracted the Maltese driver.  Croatian emergency divers described the operation to recover the car involved in the crash as one of the most difficult they had ever carried out, with experienced diver Renato Huba telling local media that while he had prepared for the worst, “this was much worse”. A member of the towing service praised a policeman who was among the first to arrive on the scene and who dived into the water in an attempt to open the door of the car damaged by the force of impact. "He tried everything he could. He jumped, dived, tried to open the door, but due to the extensive damage and the strong water pressure, it was simply not possible. He did his best," said Adrian Karamba, 24sata reported.

title: Watch: Traffic accident caught live on air during live Transport Malta interview
subtitle: Two cars involved in bumper-to-bumper during live TV interview
content: Malta’s traffic woes were brought home to TV viewers live on air after a minor accident was caught on camera during a roadside TVM interview with a Transport Malta official. The footage shows a silver vehicle crashing into the back of a red car in front as the latter stops at a Paola roundabout, as Transport Malta’s (TM) deputy head of enforcement Jean Claude Attard is interviewed in the foreground live on TVM. Attard appears startled at the sound of the accident before looking around to the scene of the bumper-to-bumper in the background, while the presenter continues speaking. The accident occurred just moments after the presenter said the pair were “here in the early hours of the morning, when traffic seems to be at its peak – which is normal for the country”.  Reacting to the incident, Attard tells the presenter: “As you can see, these things happen on the go, as behind us, we have a bumper-to-bumper which can take a while to clear the vehicles from the street”. He added that TM officials would “place markers on the ground of where the crash happened to move the cars as fast as possible” in addition to their duties directing traffic at what he described as “one of the busiest junctions in the south”. TM officials can be seen attending the scene shortly after the incident occurs. Thursday’s on-air accident comes as Malta continues to battle perennial congestion and frustration on the roads. On Tuesday, gridlock was particularly bad across the country as Malta registered 23 collisions, 10 vehicle breakdowns and two separate spillages across the island during morning rush hour. Motorists reported spending more than double the usual time on their commutes, and many took to social media to express frustration, complaining about standstill traffic that stretched even onto non-arterial roads. The issue spilt over into parliamentary proceedings later that day when Opposition Leader Alex Borg quipped to Robert Abela that he was delayed because, due to not being escorted like the prime minister, he was stuck in traffic.

title: Motorcyclist seriously injured in Żurrieq crash
subtitle: The 61-year-old man from Mqabba was taken to Mater Dei for further treatment
content: A motorcyclist was left with serious injuries after being involved in a traffic collision with a car in Żurrieq on Thursday morning. Preliminary investigations suggest a collision had occurred between the Piaggio Beverly motorbike driven by the injured party, a 61-year-old man from Mqabba, and a Toyota Aqua driven by a 67-year-old woman from Żurrieq. The incident occurred on Triq il-Belt Valletta at around 9.30am, police said. The motorcyclist was treated at the scene before being taken to Mater Dei Hospital, where his injuries were certified as serious. Magistrate Monica Borg Galea was informed of the incident and opened an inquiry into the case. Police investigations are still ongoing.

title: Car catches fire on Floriana main road, causing standstill traffic
subtitle: A police spokesperson said the driver is uninjured, and the firefighters were able to extinguish the blaze
content: A man was driving on the Floriana main road when his car caught fire on Thursday afternoon.   A police spokesperson said the driver is uninjured and the firefighters were able to extinguish the blaze soon after they arrived at Triq Sant Anna.   Readers in the area said they were caught in standstill traffic as police made their best efforts to direct oncoming vehicles.  "Even a snail was travelling faster than us," a frustrated commuter told Times of Malta. Triq Sant Anna connects Valletta to the rest of Malta and is among the island's busier roads.  Most of Malta's buses pass through that road.

title: Għajnsielem mayor urges traffic safety measures after latest road accident
subtitle: Four-vehicle collision on Triq l-Imġarr left two injured as Kevin Cauchi says 'statistics speak for themselves'
content: The Mayor of Għajnsielem on Friday called on the authorities to install speed cameras and traffic calming measures along Triq l-Imġarr after a four-vehicle collision left two people in hospital. One person suffered grievous injuries while another sustained light injuries in the accident, the latest in a string of “serious accidents” along that stretch of road which led mayor Kevin Cauchi to make his heartfelt appeal to the authorities. The accident, which happened around 9am, involved a Mitsubishi L200 driven by a 35-year old man from Xagħra and a Suzuki GSXR driven by a 43-year old man from Nadur. A 19-year old man also from Nadur was riding pillion. A Toyota Corolla driven by a 67-year old man from Qala and an Alfa Romeo driven by a 55-year old man from Munxar were also damaged in the collision. A medical team was called on site and an ambulance took the 43-year old man and the 19-year old youth to the Gozo General Hospital for treatment. Magistrate Brigitte Sultana appointed an inquiry as police investigations continued.  Writing in a social media post following the accident, Għajnsielem mayor Kevin Cauchi expressed his frustration at the lack of inaction following the latest accident on this stretch of road. “Another serious accident took place this morning on Triq l-Imġarr. The statistics speak for themselves yet still nothing is being done,” he said. He pointed out the local council has been appealing with the authority “for years” to install speed cameras, plastic bollards and other traffic calming measures along Triq l- Imġarr and other main roads.
